Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Nitrogen Retention and Ecosystem Succession: Theory Meets Data
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nitrogen is a critical nutrient for forests, and scarcity of nitrogen often limits forest growth. Theoretical considerations in ecology indicate that as a forest ages and its growth slows, its uptake of nitrogen from the soil should also slow, leading to increased loss of nitrogen in drainage water. Long-term measurements of nitrogen in streams draining the Hubbard Brook Experimental Forest in New Hampshire contradict this expected pattern. This project seeks to understand the discrepancy between the theory and the data by testing the hypothesis that young forests extract nitrogen from deep soils, but as the forest ages, re-accumulation of the nitrogen in the soil delays the loss of nitrogen in drainage water. The hypothesis will be tested by a field experiment to determine the propensity for nitrogen accumulation in soil beneath forest stands of different ages, and careful accounting of the amount of nitrogen in a sequence of forests ranging from 15 to over 200 years old. In addition, a computer simulation model of forest ecosystems will be revised to incorporate these new observations.
This work is important for management of forests to minimize loss of nitrogen, a key plant nutrient. Air pollution adds excess nitrogen to the forest, and if it is lost in drainage water, it can pollute streams and lakes. The project will involve training of two graduate students and two postdoctoral associates, and a teacher training module will help two high school science teachers develop a unit for teaching about forest ecology in their classrooms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

A central conceptual model in ecosystem ecology states that ecosystem retention of critical nutrients such as nitrogen (N) over succession should correspond directly to accumulation of biomass, typically focusing on plant biomass. In this project, we expand the model to recognize critical roles of soil organic N as a source and sink for N over succession, as plants borrow from and repay this soil ?nitrogen bank.? Early in succession, the rate of N accumulation in plants regularly exceeds the N supply from atmospheric deposition, indicating that plants likely extract N from soil. Later, when net biomass accumulation ceases, N should re-accumulate in soil to replace the N previously ?mined.? Consequently, successional patterns of stream N loss should lag those of plant biomass accumulation.

This portion of this collaborative project characterized how soil microbial processes involved in soil N acquisition (decomposition enzyme activities and gross N cycling rates) varied with each other, soil depth, and stand age (40 and 100 years and old-growth). We also measured how rates of plant N accumulation decrease with stand age, and we characterized how plant (leaf, bark, wood) and soil N stocks (to 50 cm depth) and isotopic (d15N) composition varied across an eight-site chronosequence (two sites x four ages:  20-, 40- and 100-years post-harvest, old-growth) at and near the Hubbard Brook Experimental Forest, New Hampshire. In addition, we supported field experiments using stable isotopic tracers (15N-NO3 and 15N- and 13C-labelled litter) to track the retention of inorganic and organic N in mineral soils along the chronosequence.

Our measurements of soil microbial processes showed that N cycling rates and enzyme activities per gram soil correlated strongly with soil carbon (C) concentration, which decreased exponentially with depth. However, when normalized per gram soil C, N cycling rates and specific enzyme activities remained surprisingly constant with depth. Gross N mineralization rate correlated with specific activities of those enzymes that hydrolyze N-rich glucosamine polymers and those that degrade cellulose to glucose, but not those that degrade protein or more complex C compounds. We suggest that gross N cycling measurements capture mostly the N released during microbial N recycling rather than from decomposition of complex organic matter. Microbial processes differed little across the three sites, but the youngest had the lowest ratio of C- to N-acquiring enzyme activity, consistent with greater N demands in younger stands. At all three stands, subsoils below 10 cm contributed 30-53% of all N cycling to 50 cm. Overall, even though microbial processes per gram soil decreased with depth, subsoils contributed substantially to ecosystem-scale N fluxes because of sustained microbial activity per gram soil C at depth and the large size of the mineral soil pool.

Measurements of plant and soil N pools and d15N composition showed that mineral soils could act as a source and sink for N over succession. Tree biomass N stocks increased with age to 556 kg N/ha in old-growth stands. Soil N stocks were large, averaging 8.1 t N/ha to 50 cm, and did not vary with stand age, although old-growth stands had lower C:N ratios and higher d15N than successional stands. Foliar d15N correlated with soil d15N but did not vary with stand age. However, differences between d15N in foliage and surface mineral soils corresponded with the size of surface soil N pools, in that both were smallest in 40-year-old stands and largest in old-growth, perhaps due to early N mining and later accumulation. Measurements support for the substantial capacity of mineral soils to store and supply N to regrowing forests, while illustrating challenges in detecting changes in this large N pool.

Recovery of an inorganic N tracer (15N-NO3) added to soil B horizons at the eight-site chronosequence did not vary directly by stand age, but age had an indirect effect via its influence on soil properties such as C:N ratio. Across sites, both the particulate and mineral-associated soil organic matter fractions rapidly incorporated the tracer, but recovery generally declined over the five weeks after tracer application, indicating the dynamic nature of soil pools often considered stable. These results indicate that mineral soils can provide an important short-term N sink in forests of all ages, but that these pools are subject to potential loss over longer timescales.

 Broader Impacts

This portion of this project provided education and training in forest ecosystem research for a range of students and professionals, including one postdoctoral associate, two technicians, one graduate student, one REU student who completed an honors thesis, and seven undergraduate assistants (five were women, four were URM).

More broadly, the project expands a central theory of ecosystem ecology on nutrient retention and ecosystem succession. Applications of this theory impact forest management regarding nutrient supply to regrowing forests, as well as air and water quality policy needs in predicting how forests will respond to variations in N inputs.
